problem_prompt:
Solve the following problem. What is the modular inverse of $11$, modulo $1000$?

Express your answer as an integer from $0$ to $999$, inclusive.
solution: We know that the modular inverse exists because $11$ and $1000$ are relatively prime. Notice that $1000 = 10^3$ and that $11 = 10 + 1$. Since $11 \cdot 11^{-1} \equiv 1 \pmod{1000}$, it follows that $(10+1) \cdot 11^{-1} = 10^3k + 1$ for some integer $k$. We recognize the potential sum of cubes factorization: if $k=1$, then $$10^3 + 1 = 1001 = 11 \cdot (10^2 - 10 + 1) = 11 \cdot 91.$$Thus, $11^{-1} \equiv \boxed{91} \pmod{1000}$.
gpt_response:
The modular inverse of $11$ modulo $1000$ is the integer $x$ such that $11x \equiv 1 \pmod{1000}$.

To find the modular inverse, we can use the extended Euclidean algorithm. Starting with $1000$ and $11$, we have:

\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Step} & \text{Equation} & \text{Quotient} & \text{Remainder} \\
\hline
0 & 1000 = 11 \times 90 + 10 & - & - \\
1 & 11 = 10 \times 1 + 1 & 90 & 10 \\
\hline
\end{array}

Now we perform the extended Euclidean algorithm backwards:

\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Step} & \text{Equation} & \text{Coeff. of 1000} & \text{Coeff. of 11} & \text{Coeff. of 1} \\
\hline
1 & 1 = 11 - 10 & 1 & -1 & 1 \\
2 & 10 = 1000 - 11 \times 90 & -90 & 1 & 1 \\
\hline
\end{array}

From this, we can see that the modular inverse of $11$ modulo $1000$ is $-90 \equiv 910 \pmod{1000}$.

Therefore, the modular inverse of $11$ modulo $1000$ is $\boxed{910}$.

The following is a response to a question. Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following response 91?: The modular inverse of $11$ modulo $1000$ is the integer $x$ such that $11x \equiv 1 \pmod{1000}$.

To find the modular inverse, we can use the extended Euclidean algorithm. Starting with $1000$ and $11$, we have:

\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Step} & \text{Equation} & \text{Quotient} & \text{Remainder} \\
\hline
0 & 1000 = 11 \times 90 + 10 & - & - \\
1 & 11 = 10 \times 1 + 1 & 90 & 10 \\
\hline
\end{array}

Now we perform the extended Euclidean algorithm backwards:

\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Step} & \text{Equation} & \text{Coeff. of 1000} & \text{Coeff. of 11} & \text{Coeff. of 1} \\
\hline
1 & 1 = 11 - 10 & 1 & -1 & 1 \\
2 & 10 = 1000 - 11 \times 90 & -90 & 1 & 1 \\
\hline
\end{array}

From this, we can see that the modular inverse of $11$ modulo $1000$ is $-90 \equiv 910 \pmod{1000}$.

Therefore, the modular inverse of $11$ modulo $1000$ is $\boxed{910}$.
gpt_response_correct_incorrect: Yes. The final solution obtained for the modular inverse of $11$ modulo $1000$ is 910.
